Congress

                        His cash network will more than compensate for weekends at home, allies say. 

            By 
Jake Sherman
             and 
Anna Palmer

10/25/15 01:10 PM EDT

                John Shinkle

                                            By 
                                                    Michael D'Antonio


                                            By 
                                                    Claudio Saunt


                                            By 
                                                    T.R. Goldman


                                            By 
Todd S. Purdum

Paul Ryan has been abundantly clear: As speaker of the House, he won’t spend all of his time jetting across the country to keep the National Republican Congressional Committee flush.
But far from being concerned, top GOP moneymen believe the Wisconsin Republican will be a major boon financially for the party. The national network he’s amassed as a vice presidential candidate and from coordinating the national party's spending in presidential elections give him advantages that even the highly prolific John Boehner didn’t enjoy.
Story Continued Below
“He has really strong numbers among the conservative community across the board, and across the country. He has deep developed strong relationships with some of our best supporters around the country,” said National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Greg Walden (R-Ore.). "Frankly, I don’t know more than maybe one or two other members that have that level of relationships.”
"He’s kind of a fresh new product on the market, if you will, and he will be enormously helpful and successful," Walden added.



            By 
Adam Sneed

There's no question Ryan has big shoes to fill. Boehner has raised $300 million for the NRCC since 2009. There was grumbling and some fear in the House Republican Conference when Ryan said he wanted to be with his family on the weekends, which Boehner often spent on the road raising cash. The speakership is "not a 9-to-5 job," Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R-Kansas), a Ryan critic, said this week.
But party officials are already plotting creative ways to compensate for Ryan's demand for family time. Boehner held a lot of fundraisers on the golf course. Ryan isn’t a golfer. So instead of a five-hour event playing golf, allies say, Ryan can hold two events in the same time and can bring in five times as much money by attracting many more donors. Associates also say he is unusually efficient with his time, even tending to donors on drives between events.
As Ryan nears the speakership, his political operation is beginning to take shape.
As Ways and Means chairman, Ryan had dual agreements with the NRCC and Republican National Committee, whereby he gave them each a day or two during Congressional recesses where they could send him around the country for events. Ryan has told the RNC that he will no longer do regular events for them, and instead will focus solely on the NRCC. 
During a private meeting in which he announced his candidacy, Ryan also told the House Republican Conference that he would focus solely on raising money for the NRCC . 
Ryan was prolific for the RNC during the 2012 cycle. Even before he became the vice presidential nominee, he raised $23 million for the party.



            By 
Kevin Robillard

While Ryan’s departure will certainly be a hit for the RNC, Sean Spicer, a spokesman for the committee, said Ryan’s fundraising heft will help the broader GOP “family” of committees.
“Paul Ryan has been an unbelievable fundraiser and supporter of the RNC and the party writ large,” Spicer said. “If he becomes speaker, it would be a huge help to have him at the NRCC.”
Top NRCC officials agree. Despite his desire to go home on weekends, many top officials think Ryan can be as prodigious as Boehner. He’s already a top surrogate for the NRCC. He has contributed $2.7 million to the party committee since 2011 – not counting events he has held for candidates and colleagues, according to a source familiar with the committee’s fundraising.
"He is in high demand," said Walden, "because he can articulate the issues, he gives a great vision discussion about the future of the party and where we can go. And he’s very likable. And so, we’ve helped him manage that demand ... at the NRCC to maximize his time because it’s so valuable.”
Ryan still has a lot of work to do. As his staff prepares for the enormity of the speakership, they also have to build a political operation. Boehner had his own political staff, dubbed "Team Boehner," that had office space at the NRCC and worked closely with the committee in scheduling events and Boehner’s travel. Ryan can go that route, or he could hand over his political operation to the committee itself. 
Boehner's operation was massive. He traveled for an entire month every summer, in addition to holding events throughout the year. 

Congress

            By 
John Bresnahan
             and 
Jake Sherman

Boehner and Ryan also have different styles and demeanors. Boehner is a back-slapping political animal, while Ryan is an affable policy wonk.
"Donors tend to be as attracted to the personality as much as they are to the office,” said Dan Senor, a close Ryan confidant who works with billionaire hedge fund manager Paul Singer in New York. “The donor community likes spending time with Paul because he's a very smart guy and he's very thoughtful and he's not just buried in process but he can also talk about policy and a governing agenda.”
Senor added that while he understands the concerns about Ryan's family time cutting into fundraising time, "when he is out fundraising he is very efficient and he accomplishes a lot.”
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: His cash network will more than compensate for weekends at home, allies say.
title: GOP moneymen: Ryan a fundraising juggernaut
